title: What are the implications of Gödel's incompleteness theorems? - Quora

response.answer_text: What are the implications of Godel’s theorems? This question has become remarkably controversial, especially in decent decades. So let me answer by first stating what every person who understands the theorems seems to agree on. It’s mainly this: For any given system of definitions and axioms, powerful enough to express number theory, there will be some propositions that can be neither proved nor disproved. That much, I believe, is not controversial. But what does it mean in practical terms? Does it mean that mathematicians have to give up their work? No. Because periodically, mathematicians come up with new branches of math, or new axioms, or new ways to make connections between the different branches. (That’s how Fermat’s Last Theorem was proved.) So it doesn’t stop the work of mathematicians at all. Math goes on as before. To many people, therefore, Godel’s Theorems stand as a kind of Humble Pie, showing limitations to our understanding, but not ending the work of mathematicians, scientists, or philosophers. Now, here comes a slightly more controversial part. Russell & Whitehead, in Principia Mathematica, tried to suggest that all the truths of math follow by definition… that is, if you simply defined every mathematical term with sufficient clarity, then 1 + 1 = 2 would follow by definition. But so, in theory, would every true mathematical proposition. Even very complex and challenging ones. I would argue that Godel spelled the doom of that project. Before anyone protests too loudly, I will one last time summarize my argument: If all the truths of math followed by definition, then someone would in theory be able to come up with a perfect set of definitions.That set of definitions would create a system S, of definitions and/or axioms. (Because according to Russell & Whitehead, all we ultimately need are definitions, in combination with deductive logic. Or we can think of an axiom as a kind of definition.)However, Godel showed that given any system S, we can find a proposition G that cannot be proved but must be true if S is consistent. (And if S is inconsistent it must be thrown out anyway.)Step (3) above contradicts the assumption that we could prove all true mathematical propositions by just having sufficiently good definitions.Given that our assumption in step (1) results in a contradiction, it must therefore be false.Look at it this way. I don’t have to prove anything at all by my argument, except one thing: Starting with the assumption that we CAN prove all true propositions of math by definition, then, following Godel’s reasoning, we reach a contradiction. Therefore, it cannot be said that all true propositions of math follow by definition. And if that’s true (as I would argue it is), then I would further conclude that math is synthetic… that is to say, the propositions of math do not have the character “All bachelors [in the ordinary sense of the word] are unmarried.” This “bachelor” proposition is analytic, not synthetic, because the truth follows directly from the words themselves. Synthetic knowledge, according to most philosophers, especially empiricists, is not “real knowledge.” Now, there is a counter-argument, of sorts, to this, and it goes as follows: It is not meaningful, ultimately, to speak of “mathematical truth,” because there are different maths, or different “worlds,” depending on which axioms you initially choose to accept. Such as: do you accept the Parallel Postulate in geometry, or do you accept the Axiom of Choice? I concede that there are “fuzzy” areas like this at the frontiers of math. There are more than one geometries, for example; and there do seem to be more than one “math,” in how one chooses to approach infinity as a concept. However, my argument earlier still stands, I believe. Given any system of math, in any “world,” powerful enough to express numbers, you will find that it is incorrect to ever say, “All true propositions in this area follow by definition.” Because of my reductio ad absurdum. And that’s huge. If you cannot say that for any system, powerful enough to express numbers, then we conclude: All true propositions do NOT follow by definition. Furthermore, I would argue that this makes math analytic. It is not just trivial knowledge, as Russell asserted. That’s a big word, but if I am correct (and there is still some controversy) it means that math is not simply a branch of logic. And that means that Godel settled a rather old argument!!

Thank you for the A2A. I hope to clear up some misconceptions about the implications of Gödel's theorems by providing a quick informal walkthrough of his first incompleteness theorem, along with some commentary that should make it clear that the consequences of the theorem only directly pertain to a very particular sort of simulation game, and have no necessary “real world,” i.e. metaphysical, epistemological or ethical, implications for things that are not “actually encompassed” (whatever that means) by the simulation game in question without additional and most often entirely unjustifiable philosophical assumptions or paradigms, which are beyond the scope of mathematical formalisms, and have nothing to do with the contents of the theorem itself. The game Gödel invites us to play I will call “Gödel’s Formal Systematization of Arithmetic and Beyond,” and it is a formal syntactical simulation of the normative semantical notions we tend to have about logic, proof, and truth. But I stress the most important point about this theorem that people tend to be fooled about, not just with respect to Gödel’s theorems, but about mathematics in general: a simulation is in general NOT the real deal. The map is not the territory. In effect, Gödel's theorems are demonstrative of the limitations that simulations can have that the “real deal” does not necessarily have.  The Rules of Gödel's Game Consider a finite collection of symbols, whose name is [math]F[/math]. Such a collection is called an alphabet. We can string these symbols together into finite lines of symbols, appropriately called finite strings. I will write these strings with single quotes around them. For example, if our alphabet is just [math]A[/math], [math]B[/math], and [math]C[/math], some finite strings over this alphabet are the string with no symbols ‘’ (whose name is typically [math]\epsilon[/math]), ‘[math]AABCCAB[/math]’, ‘[math]BCABC[/math]’, ‘[math]A[/math]’ , etc. We can start by talking about what Gödel calls a formal language over [math]F[/math], which is simply a set of finite strings with symbols from [math]F[/math]. Our formal language we will call [math]L(F)[/math]. The strings in [math]L(F)[/math] are called well-formed formulas. Next, we can establish a system of formal logical deduction over these well-formed formulas. The way we do this is to introduce “logical connectives,” and to specify which formulas can be formally deduced from others, as well as a formal “truth evaluation” structure. For example, if one formula [math]Q[/math] can be deduced from another formula [math]P[/math], we will write [math](P\implies Q)[/math]. We can denote the formal negation of [math]P[/math] by [math]\neg(P)[/math], we can denote “[math]P[/math] or [math]Q[/math]” by [math](P\vee Q)[/math], and “[math]P[/math] and [math]Q[/math]” by [math](P\wedge Q)[/math]. Then, we can construct formal truth tables to establish the method of formal evaluation. For example, if [math]P[/math] is “true” and [math]Q[/math] is “false,” then the formal truth table will tell us that [math](P\implies Q)[/math] is “false.” Of course, all of this is still formal. “True” and “false” are formal syntactical objects here--we could just as easily call them “green” and “East.” It is syntax we use to attempt to formally simulate logic--it is not the “real deal” itself. Afterall, in effect, it’s only symbols on paper. With this formal system of deduction in place, we have what Gödel calls a formal system. In effect, we have constructed a particular formal simulator for propositions and logic over those propositions. All's well and good so far I hope. But we aren't done yet. Remember the name of the game--we are trying to systematize arithmetic.  Formally Systematizing Arithmetic In our alphabet, we will be sure to include the symbols necessary to simulate arithmetic on natural numbers using the Peano arithmetic simulator. This means that we will have a symbol [math]0[/math] that we will use to denote zero, as well as a symbol [math]S[/math] that we will use to denote succession. For example, [math]S0[/math] is one, [math]SS0[/math] is two, etc. We will also use the operator symbols such as parentheses, the plus sign, the equals sign, existential quantifiers, the cross for multiplication, and all the other fixings we use to simulate such arithmetic as usual. But we will also introduce a symbol that introduces new symbols. For example, [math]x[/math] is some base symbol we can introduce, and [math]x*[/math] is a new symbol, and [math]x**[/math] is a third symbol, etc. We can name these symbols how we like, understanding that they can be tabulated and converted into the formal symbolism of our language. And in the end, we make sure still to have only countably many symbols.  Gödel Numbering This is where things get interesting. Since our language simulates arithmetic, we can use it to try to talk about natural numbers. We can make statements about them, for example ‘[math]SS0+S0=SSS0[/math]’ is a “true” well-formed formula. It amounts to saying [math]2+1=3[/math]. We also have “false” formulas, like ‘[math]S0=0[/math]’ And so on. Notice that there are rules for being well-formed, and separate rules for being either “true” or “false”--there are statements we take to be formally true in an explicit manner, called axioms, and there are other statements that are formally true in an implicit manner, by virtue of the formal truth evaluation structure and formal logical deduction mechanisms inherent to our formal system, called theorems. Now keep in mind, we have countably many symbols. What this means is that we can associate each symbol to a number, just by listing them. For example, we might associate [math]0[/math] with [math]1[/math], [math]S[/math] with [math]2[/math], [math]+[/math] with [math]3[/math], [math]=[/math] with [math]4[/math], [math]×[/math] with [math]5[/math], etc. This association is given by [math]G[/math], so that [math]G(0)=1[/math], [math]G(+)=3[/math], etc. These are called Gödel numbers. And since our well-formed formulas are finite strings, we can also associate each well-formed formula to a unique number, using the unique factorization of integers into primes. For example, we can make associations as follows: [math]G([/math]‘[math]0+S0=S0[/math]’[math])=2^1 3^3 5^2 7^1 11^4 13^2 17^1[/math] The exponents on successive primes tell us which symbol is found in which position of the well-formed formula. Take a second to absorb that. It is a large number, but it is still a number. And notice, if we were given any Gödel number, we could factor it into primes, and construct its corresponding string of symbols from our alphabet. So this process is reversible, and we also have Gödel numbers for well-formed formulas. We can also create Gödel numbers for finite sequences of well-formed formulas. What we can do is skip a prime between the formulas, and use the same exponential sequence, just on larger successive primes. And hence, since formal proofs are nothing more than finite sequences of well-formed formulas that follow our formal laws of deduction, we can establish Gödel numbers for proofs of well-formed formulas.  The Gödel Sentence We have created a system of symbols that talks about numbers, and also a system of numbers that talks about symbols. So we can use these systems together to let the system of symbols talk about itself. Now we can introduce a symbol [math]P(x,y)[/math], which can be interpreted as “[math]x[/math] is the Gödel number of a proof of the statement encoded by the Gödel number [math]y[/math].” So using the existential quantifier, if [math]Z[/math] is a well-formed formula, we can make the statement ‘[math]\exists x:P(x,G(Z))[/math]’ Which says, “There exists a formal proof of [math]Z[/math].” Similarly, we can write ‘[math]\neg(\exists x:P(x,G(Z))[/math]’ Which says, “There does not exist a formal proof of [math]Z[/math].” Call this last well-formed formula [math]W(Z)[/math], or [math]W[/math] for short. Well, what about [math]W(W)[/math]? What does this statement say? Think about it. It says “There does not exist a formal proof of this very statement.” Well, if [math]W(W)[/math] is false, then we have a formal proof of [math]W(W)[/math], which means our formal system is not consistent--it proves something that is logically false. Otherwise, [math]W(W)[/math] is true, and hence there is no formal proof of [math]W(W)[/math]. But this means that there is a true statement about our system that cannot be proven within the system itself, and hence that in this kind of simulation game, “truth is strictly stronger than proof.” Such a statement is called a Gödel sentence, and Gödel's first incompleteness theorem amounts to the existence of at least one such sentence, while its formal proof is by direct construction. Of course, this only pertains to the simulation game. It does not necessarily apply to the “real deal,” but it certainly limits our ability to formalize useful deductive systems about arithmetic, and in this sense its “real world” (i.e. nonmathematical) implications are mostly contained to theoretical computer science. That is Gödel's first incompleteness theorem in an informal nutshell. I hope that made enough sense, and I encourage you to read a formal proof--this was not one. Thanks for reading!
